Professor | location= | website= }} '''Sir William Alexander Craigie''' ([[1867]] – [[1957]]) was a philologist, lexicographer and [[University of Oxford|Oxford]] professor. He was [[J.R.R. Tolkien]]'s immediate predecessor as [[Rawlinson and Bosworth Professor of Anglo-Saxon]] from [[1916]] to [[1925]]. ==Biography== William Craigie was born in [[Wikipedia:Dundee|Dundee, Scotland]] and as a child developed a love for languages, particularly Scottish Gaelic. He enrolled at the [[Wikipedia:University of St Andrews|University of St Andrews]] where he studied German, French, Danish and Icelandic. He was awarded a scholarship to study at [[Wikipedia:Balliol College, Oxford|Balliol College, Oxford]] where he began learning Celtic.{{webcite|author=Glenn Mills|articleurl=https://museumoftheuniversityofstandrews.wordpress.com/2018/09/03/sir-william-alexander-craigie-a-man-of-many-words/|articlename=Sir William Alexander Craigie: A Man of Many Words|dated=3 September 2018|website=[https://museumoftheuniversityofstandrews.wordpress.com/ Museum of the University of St Andrews]|accessed=25 February 2024}} In [[1897]], Craigie was the third editor hired to work on the ''[[Oxford English Dictionary]]''. He worked on N, Q, R, U, and V, Si–Sq, and Wo–Wy;Tolkien also worked on entries beginning with W. in total his work accounting for one-fifth of the original dictionary. He was Taylorian lecturer in the Scandinavian languages in [[1904]] before becoming Rawlinson and Bosworth professor of Anglo-Saxon in 1916 until his resignation in 1925.{{webcite|author=A. J. Aitken|articleurl=https://www.oxforddnb.com/display/10.1093/ref:odnb/9780198614128.001.0001/odnb-9780198614128-e-32614?rskey=Bufk8H&result=2|articlename=Craigie, Sir William Alexander|dated=23 September 2004|website=[https://www.oxforddnb.com/ Oxford Dictionary of National Biography]|accessed=25 February 2024}} After Craigie's resignation Tolkien applied for,{{L|7}} and held the position until [[1945]].{{webcite|author=[[Tom Shippey]]|articleurl=https://w3.ric.edu/faculty/rpotter/temp/tolkien_DNB.pdf|articlename=Tolkien, John Ronald Reuel|dated=23 September 2004|website=[https://www.oxforddnb.com/ Oxford Dictionary of National Biography]|accessed=25 February 2024}} ==External links== * {{WP|William Craigie}} {{references|notes}} [[Category:British people|Craigie, William]] [[Category:Linguists|Craigie, William]] [[Category:People by name|Craigie, William]] __NOTOC__
